newsitem.title: USA: N.Y. Pataki says still reviewing welfare reforms.
newsitem.headline: N.Y. Pataki says still reviewing welfare reforms.

text.p: New York Governor George Pataki, who has estimated that the dramatic federal welfare reforms will cost the state "several hundred million dollars," said on Wednesday that a bipartisan group still is studying the issue.
"The task force is continuing its work, a line-by-line review of a 300-page bill," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the governor.
Pataki has not set a deadline for the group to finish its work, the spokesman said, explaining the governor wants it to be as thorough as possible.

And the governor has backed off on his earlier suggestion that a special legislative session might be needed to deal with the new federal reforms. "That is not an issue that we've addressed at this point," his spokesman said.
The governor went to Utica, in Oneida County, on Wednesday to highlight the area's success in reducing the number of people who collect welfare.

In the past year, Oneida County has cut the number of welfare recipients by 2,700, McKeon said, adding that New York state as a whole reduced the program's rolls by 181,000 from January 1995 to May 1996.
The drop reflects Pataki's efforts to shift people from welfare to work, he said.
